---
title: "sin(A)cos(B) = [sin(A+B) + sin(A-B)]/2"
categories: ["Trignometry" , "Product-to-Sum Formulas"]


---



**Proof:**

We aim to prove that:

$$\sin(A)\cos(B) = \frac{\sin(A+B) + \sin(A-B)}{2}$$

**Recall the Sine Addition and Subtraction Formulas**

The sine addition formula states:

$$\sin(A + B) = \sin A \cos B + \cos A \sin B$$The sine subtraction formula states:$$\sin(A - B) = \sin A \cos B - \cos A \sin B$$

**Add the Two Equations Together**

Add $\sin(A + B)$and$\sin(A - B)$:

$$\sin(A + B) + \sin(A - B) = (\sin A \cos B + \cos A \sin B) + (\sin A \cos B - \cos A \sin B)$$Simplify the right-hand side:$$= 2 \sin A \cos B$$

**Divide Both Sides by 2**

To isolate $\sin A \cos B$, divide both sides of the equation by 2:

$$\frac{\sin(A + B) + \sin(A - B)}{2} = \sin A \cos B$$

**Conclusion:**

Thus, we have shown that:

$$\sin(A)\cos(B) = \frac{\sin(A+B) + \sin(A-B)}{2}$$which completes the proof.$\boxed{\sin(A)\cos(B) = \dfrac{\sin(A+B) + \sin(A-B)}{2}}$
